key_insight: The paper introduces neural stochastic differential equations that learn state-dependent drift and diffusion to generatively model single-cell dynamics, yielding more accurate and realistic trajectories than prior methods. This enables simulation of perturbations to probe development and disease processes.
problem_solved: How to model continuous-time, stochastic cell-state dynamics from single-cell data while capturing state-dependent variability and enabling counterfactual/perturbation simulations.
method: Fit a neural SDE where both drift and diffusion are parameterized by neural networks conditioned on the cell state (state-dependent noise and mean dynamics).
Train the model as a generative continuous-time model to match observed single-cell trajectories and distributions, allowing sampling of realistic stochastic paths.
Use the learned dynamics to simulate perturbations (counterfactual interventions) and compare emergent trajectories for developmental or disease hypotheses.
impact: Provides ML practitioners a flexible, interpretable continuous-time generative framework for complex stochastic systems, useful for realistic simulation, uncertainty modeling, and counterfactual analysis in biology and beyond.
visual_elements: Diagram of a neural SDE block showing state input → neural drift and neural diffusion → stochastic update
Overlay plot of observed vs. simulated single-cell trajectories on a low-dimensional manifold (colored by cell type/time)
Perturbation panel showing baseline trajectory vs. intervention-induced trajectory divergence
Heatmap or vector field of learned drift + diffusion magnitude across state space
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
